articles.title: On World Migratory Bird Day, the Caribbean focuses on shared spaces
articles.summary: The occasion unites people across the Americas in a shared commitment to securing a bright and sustainable future for these marvellous migrants: healthier habitats for birds and, by extension, people.
articles.content:
This article first appeared in Birds Caribbean on September 16, 2025. An edited version, with additional contributions from Global Voices author Emma Lewis, an avid birdwatcher and member of Birds Caribbean, is being republished on Global Voices with permission.

And they’re off! The issue of migration is always a hot topic in the Americas, but on Saturday, October 11, 2025, the focus is on the feathered kind of migrant. World Migratory Bird Day (WMBD) is annually celebrated on the second Saturday of October in Latin America and the Caribbean.

Twice each year, these winged, nocturnal nomads slip through immigration, flying across the American continent and down to the Caribbean region in the autumn, then back to the United States in the spring. They come in waves, millions of them, as chronicled on the BirdCast website, which confirmed a new record night of migration — 1.25 billion birds — on October 8.

Just as with human movement, these amazing journeys are not without their dangers, and migratory birds must be protected. What if, instead of driving them away, our cities could actually save them? Is it possible to create spaces where birds and people can thrive together?

The WMBD 2025 theme “Shared Spaces: Creating Bird-Friendly Cities and Communities” calls on us to flock together to accelerate life-sustaining action for nature’s frequent fliers. The event unites people across the Americas in a shared commitment to securing a bright and sustainable future for these marvellous migrants in a global initiative to create healthier habitats for birds and, by extension, people.

Shared spaces, shared benefits

Creating bird-friendly communities is vital for helping bird populations — especially important on Caribbean islands, where towns and cities are often directly adjacent to, or interspersed among, forests, wetlands, and coastal ecosystems. Urban development on an island inherently leads to habitat loss and fragmentation, directly impacting birds’ abilities to find adequate food, as well as places to raise their families and safely hide from predators.

Urban sprawl is a significant driver of some of the major threats facing birds, with climate change creating another series of deadly threats. Rising sea levels, catastrophic hurricanes, and changes in temperature and rainfall patterns directly endanger coastal wetlands and other natural habitats that birds rely on.

According to BirdLife Jamaica President Justin Saunders, “Migratory Birds and Jamaicans have quite an interesting relationship. Some Jamaicans readily recognize a few, like the American Redstart (Setophaga ruticilla) and refer to it as ‘Christmas bud’ [bird]; others will express complete amazement when they see the Chestnut-sided warbler (Setophaga pensilvanica), which is much rarer.”

He believes that Jamaicans have “a growing love for these long-distance migrants, who feel like resident birds to many of us, and our forests, rivers, and urban spaces provide critical habitat for [them] to rest and recharge as they escape the cold winter abroad.” Saunders remains concerned, however, that such spaces “are coming under increasing pressure from land-clearance, urban sprawl, and, of course, the effects of climate change.” Birdlife Jamaica, he says, is committed to “educating and advocating for more meaningful and considerate actions at all levels of society so we can continue to enjoy these shared spaces and welcome all our feathered friends into them.”

This is why every patch of green space, whether it’s a park, a backyard, or a tree-lined street, becomes a critical part of the larger ecological network on each island. Such shared green spaces are a win-win: they protect birds while also providing cool, peaceful refuges for people, offering places to relax and improve mental health. Bird-friendly communities that incorporate green infrastructure like mangrove restoration and urban forests can provide a buffer against climate impacts like flooding and rising temperatures. By investing in these environments, we build a comfortable and sustainable future for all.

Meet the WMBD ambassadors

Each year, Environment for the Americas (EFTA) selects certain bird species as ambassadors of World Migratory Bird Day. This year, the eight focal species include the American Robin (Turdus migratoriu), Peregrine Falcon (Falco peregrinus), Red Knot (Calidris canutus), American Redstart (Setophaga ruticilla), Giant Hummingbird (Patagona gigas), Graylag Goose (Anser anser), Common Crane (Grus grus), and Yellow-breasted Bunting (Emberiza aureola). They can all be spotted in the Americas’ Flyways, as well as in the flyways of Europe, Africa, and Asia.

Laying out the welcome mat

Creating bird-friendly spaces to welcome species like these doesn’t have to be exhausting or expensive. Small, daily actions, like choosing coffee brewed from bird-friendly beans, can support birdlife — especially given that worldwide, 49 percent of all bird species are in decline. The World Wildlife Fund's 2024 Living Planet Report also noted population decrease, while a BirdLife press release that same year revealed that migratory shorebird populations were plummeting worldwide.

BirdsCaribbean Executive Director Lisa Sorensen says that migratory birds are more imperilled than ever: “Climate change, coastal development, pollution, and pressures from tourism are shrinking the critical Caribbean stopover sites they depend on,” she explains, “but it rests in our power to decide their fate. Every remaining patch of habitat is a lifeline; we must act to protect them now or watch these migrations fade from our shores.”

Other bird-friendly actions include opting for native plants, reducing the use of artificial light, avoiding pesticides, combating collisions by using window films and patterned glass or closing curtains, and preventing plastic pollution.

In that vein, Caribbean educators have been busy preparing for World Migratory Bird Day via an array of events. These include birdwatching trips, habitat cleanups, art competitions, presentations in schools, tree planting, and even the installation of bird baths and feeders around community buildings, whereby participants can learn about migratory birds, the adaptations they go through, and the challenges they face on their incredible journeys.

It emphasizes broad environmental benefits, including habitat preservation, climate resilience, and community engagement, with concrete actions and educational efforts detailed. articles.personality_title: Caribbean communities unite to protect migratory birds and their habitats
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Every year, millions of birds travel between North America and the Caribbean, facing many dangers along the way. These birds depend on safe places to rest and feed during their long journeys. World Migratory Bird Day, celebrated in October, brings attention to protecting these birds and their habitats.

**What happened** – On October 11, 2025, people across the Americas, especially in the Caribbean, joined efforts to create bird-friendly spaces in cities and towns. This year's theme, "Shared Spaces: Creating Bird-Friendly Cities and Communities," encouraged communities to protect habitats like parks, wetlands, and forests that birds need to survive. Activities included birdwatching, tree planting, cleaning habitats, and building bird feeders.

**Impact** – Protecting these shared green spaces helps both birds and people. Birds get safe places to rest and breed, while communities enjoy cooler, cleaner environments that improve health and reduce climate risks like flooding. This effort is important because many bird species are declining due to habitat loss, climate change, and pollution. In the Caribbean, where cities often overlap with natural areas, these actions are crucial for saving migratory birds.

**What's next step** – Groups like BirdsCaribbean and Environment for the Americas will continue educating people and promoting bird-friendly actions. They encourage simple daily steps, such as planting native plants, reducing light pollution, and avoiding pesticides. These efforts aim to maintain healthy bird populations and ensure future generations can enjoy the sights and sounds of migratory birds.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Caribbean communities are working together to protect migratory birds by creating safe, green spaces that benefit both wildlife and people.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les communautés des Caraïbes unies pour protéger les oiseaux migrateurs et leurs habitats
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Chaque année, des millions d’oiseaux voyagent entre l’Amérique du Nord et les Caraïbes, affrontant de nombreux dangers en chemin. Ces oiseaux ont besoin d’endroits sûrs pour se reposer et se nourrir durant leurs longs voyages. La Journée mondiale des oiseaux migrateurs, célébrée en octobre, attire l’attention sur la protection de ces oiseaux et de leurs habitats.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 11 octobre 2025, des personnes à travers les Amériques, notamment dans les Caraïbes, ont uni leurs efforts pour créer des espaces favorables aux oiseaux dans les villes et villages. Le thème de cette année, « Espaces partagés : créer des villes et communautés accueillantes pour les oiseaux », a encouragé la protection des habitats comme les parcs, zones humides et forêts indispensables aux oiseaux. Des activités comme l’observation des oiseaux, la plantation d’arbres, le nettoyage des habitats et l’installation de mangeoires ont eu lieu.

**Impact** – Protéger ces espaces verts profite aux oiseaux et aux habitants. Les oiseaux trouvent des lieux sûrs pour se reposer et se reproduire, tandis que les communautés bénéficient d’un environnement plus frais et plus sain, aidant aussi à réduire les risques liés au climat comme les inondations. Cette action est cruciale car beaucoup d’espèces d’oiseaux déclinent à cause de la perte d’habitat, du changement climatique et de la pollution. Aux Caraïbes, où villes et nature se côtoient souvent, ces efforts sont essentiels pour sauver les oiseaux migrateurs.

**Étape suivante** – Des groupes comme BirdsCaribbean et Environment for the Americas continueront à informer le public et à promouvoir des gestes favorables aux oiseaux. Ils encouragent des actions simples au quotidien, comme planter des espèces locales, réduire la pollution lumineuse et éviter les pesticides. L’objectif est de préserver des populations d’oiseaux saines pour que les générations futures puissent encore admirer ces voyageurs ailés.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les communautés caribéennes travaillent ensemble pour protéger les oiseaux migrateurs en créant des espaces verts sûrs qui profitent à la faune et aux humains.
articles.personality_title_es: Comunidades del Caribe se unen para proteger a las aves migratorias y sus hábitats
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Cada año, millones de aves viajan entre Norteamérica y el Caribe, enfrentando muchos peligros en el camino. Estas aves necesitan lugares seguros para descansar y alimentarse durante sus largos viajes. El Día Mundial de las Aves Migratorias, que se celebra en octubre, llama la atención sobre la protección de estas aves y sus hábitats.

**Qué pasó** – El 11 de octubre de 2025, personas de toda América, especialmente en el Caribe, se unieron para crear espacios amigables para las aves en ciudades y pueblos. El tema de este año, "Espacios compartidos: creando ciudades y comunidades amigables con las aves", motivó a proteger hábitats como parques, humedales y bosques que las aves necesitan para sobrevivir. Hubo actividades como observación de aves, plantación de árboles, limpieza de hábitats y construcción de comederos.

**Impacto** – Proteger estos espacios verdes beneficia tanto a las aves como a las personas. Las aves encuentran lugares seguros para descansar y reproducirse, mientras las comunidades disfrutan de ambientes más frescos y saludables que también ayudan a reducir riesgos climáticos como inundaciones. Esta acción es importante porque muchas especies están en declive debido a la pérdida de hábitat, el cambio climático y la contaminación. En el Caribe, donde las ciudades a menudo están cerca de áreas naturales, estas acciones son vitales para salvar a las aves migratorias.

**Próximo paso** – Organizaciones como BirdsCaribbean y Environment for the Americas seguirán educando y promoviendo acciones amigables con las aves. Recomiendan pasos simples diarios, como plantar plantas nativas, reducir la contaminación lumínica y evitar pesticidas. Estos esfuerzos buscan mantener poblaciones saludables de aves para que las futuras generaciones puedan seguir disfrutando de ellas.

**Resumen en una frase** – Las comunidades del Caribe trabajan juntas para proteger a las aves migratorias creando espacios verdes seguros que benefician a la vida silvestre y a las personas.

articles.title: Scientists unearth a 112-million-year-old time capsule filled with ancient insects
articles.summary: Researchers have unearthed South America’s first amber deposits containing ancient insects in an Ecuadorian quarry, offering a rare 112-million-year-old glimpse into life on the supercontinent Gondwana. The amber, found in the Hollín Formation, preserved a diverse range of insect species and plant material, revealing a humid, resin-rich forest teeming with life.
articles.content:
Scientists have uncovered the first South American amber deposits containing preserved insects in a quarry in Ecuador, according to a study published in Communications Earth & Environment. The discovery captures a vivid picture of a 112-million-year-old forest that once thrived on the ancient supercontinent Gondwana and opens new doors for exploring a long-overlooked prehistoric ecosystem.

Amber (fossilized tree resin) has been found in samples dating back as far as 320 million years, but it became far more common between 120 million and 70 million years ago, during the Cretaceous era (143.1 million to 66 million years ago). These ancient resins sometimes contain "bio-inclusions" -- trapped remains of plants or animals -- that offer rare, detailed glimpses of life forms such as insects and flowers that are not usually preserved as fossils. Until now, nearly all known major amber deposits were located in the Northern Hemisphere, leaving scientists with limited insight into what Southern Hemisphere ecosystems looked like during the time when the continents were beginning to separate from Gondwana.

To investigate, Xavier Delclòs and his research team examined amber and surrounding rock samples collected from the Genoveva quarry in Ecuador. The amber, dated to roughly 112 million years ago, belongs to the Hollín Formation, a sedimentary layer that stretches across Ecuador's Oriente Basin. The team identified two distinct kinds of amber: one formed underground near the roots of resin-producing plants, and another that developed in the open air. Among 60 samples of the latter, the researchers found 21 bio-inclusions representing five insect orders, including Diptera (flies), Coleoptera (beetles), and Hymenoptera (a group that includes ants and wasps), as well as a fragment of spider web. In addition, the rock surrounding the amber contained numerous plant fossils such as spores, pollen, and other botanical traces.

According to the researchers, the characteristics of the fossils indicate that the amber originated in a warm, humid forest filled with dense vegetation and resin-producing trees in southern Gondwana. They emphasize that this rare find provides a crucial new resource for understanding life and biodiversity during this key period in Earth's history.
articles.reasoning: The discovery of South America's first amber deposits with ancient insects offers significant new insights into prehistoric ecosystems on the Gondwana supercontinent, enhancing scientific understanding of biodiversity and Earth's history with broad implications for paleontology and conservation.
articles.personality_title: Scientists discover 112-million-year-old amber with ancient insects in Ecuador
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have long studied amber, which is fossilized tree resin that can trap and preserve tiny plants and animals. Most amber finds have come from the Northern Hemisphere, leaving little information about prehistoric life in the Southern Hemisphere, especially on the ancient supercontinent Gondwana.

**What happened** – A research team led by Xavier Delclòs found the first amber deposits in South America containing ancient insects. These were discovered in a quarry in Ecuador, in a rock layer called the Hollín Formation. The amber is about 112 million years old and includes preserved insects like flies, beetles, ants, and wasps, as well as parts of spider webs and plant remains.

**Impact** – This discovery gives scientists a rare and detailed look at a warm, humid forest that existed in southern Gondwana long ago. It helps fill a big gap in knowledge about what kinds of plants and insects lived in South America during the Cretaceous period. These fossils can teach us more about Earth’s biodiversity and how ecosystems have changed over millions of years.

**What's next step** – Researchers plan to study the amber and its trapped fossils more closely to learn about the relationships between ancient species and their environment. This may lead to new discoveries about how forests and insects evolved in the Southern Hemisphere.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Scientists uncovered South America’s first amber with ancient insects, revealing a 112-million-year-old forest ecosystem on the Gondwana supercontinent.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des scientifiques découvrent de l'ambre vieille de 112 millions d'années avec des insectes anciens en Équateur
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L'ambre, résine d'arbre fossilisée, peut piéger de petites plantes et animaux. La plupart des découvertes d'ambre viennent de l'hémisphère nord, ce qui limite les informations sur la vie préhistorique dans l'hémisphère sud, notamment sur l'ancien supercontinent Gondwana.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Une équipe dirigée par Xavier Delclòs a trouvé les premiers dépôts d'ambre en Amérique du Sud contenant des insectes anciens. Cette découverte a eu lieu dans une carrière en Équateur, dans une couche rocheuse appelée Formation Hollín. L'ambre, âgé d'environ 112 millions d'années, contient des insectes comme des mouches, coléoptères, fourmis et guêpes, ainsi que des parties de toiles d'araignées et des restes de plantes.

**Impact** – Cette découverte offre un aperçu rare et détaillé d'une forêt chaude et humide qui existait autrefois dans le sud de Gondwana. Elle comble un important manque de connaissances sur les plantes et insectes vivant en Amérique du Sud durant le Crétacé. Ces fossiles aident à mieux comprendre la biodiversité de la Terre et l'évolution des écosystèmes sur des millions d'années.

**Prochaines étapes** – Les chercheurs vont étudier plus en détail l'ambre et ses fossiles pour mieux comprendre les liens entre les espèces anciennes et leur environnement. Cela pourrait mener à de nouvelles découvertes sur l'évolution des forêts et des insectes dans l'hémisphère sud.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Les scientifiques ont découvert le premier ambre d'Amérique du Sud avec des insectes anciens, révélant un écosystème forestier vieux de 112 millions d'années sur le supercontinent Gondwana.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos descubren ámbar de 112 millones de años con insectos antiguos en Ecuador
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El ámbar es resina de árbol fosilizada que puede atrapar y conservar pequeños animales y plantas. La mayoría de los hallazgos de ámbar provienen del hemisferio norte, por lo que se sabe poco sobre la vida prehistórica en el hemisferio sur, especialmente en el antiguo supercontinente Gondwana.

**Qué pasó** – Un equipo de investigación liderado por Xavier Delclòs encontró los primeros depósitos de ámbar en Sudamérica que contienen insectos antiguos. Fue descubierto en una cantera en Ecuador, en una capa de roca llamada Formación Hollín. El ámbar tiene unos 112 millones de años e incluye insectos como moscas, escarabajos, hormigas y avispas, además de partes de telas de araña y restos vegetales.

**Impacto** – Este hallazgo ofrece una visión rara y detallada de un bosque cálido y húmedo que existió en el sur de Gondwana hace mucho tiempo. Ayuda a llenar un gran vacío en el conocimiento sobre qué plantas e insectos vivían en Sudamérica durante el período Cretácico. Estos fósiles pueden enseñar más sobre la biodiversidad de la Tierra y cómo han cambiado los ecosistemas en millones de años.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores planean estudiar más a fondo el ámbar y sus fósiles para entender mejor las relaciones entre las especies antiguas y su ambiente. Esto podría conducir a nuevos descubrimientos sobre la evolución de los bosques y los insectos en el hemisferio sur.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Científicos descubrieron el primer ámbar de Sudamérica con insectos antiguos, revelando un ecosistema forestal de 112 millones de años en el supercontinente Gondwana.
